data.title: On exit with modified file, "don't save" and "cancel" actions are swapped
data.body: I see this in 0.10.4.  If I press `Cancel` the app exits (the don't save case).  If I press `Don't Save` the dialog closes but VSCode stays running (the cancel case).

data.title: problem matcher that clears only for changed files

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I have a watch task that runs various per-file checks (lint, appropriate tests, etc). When it starts up, it runs those checks for all files in the project.  Thereafter, it only runs checks on files that change.

For the most part, it works great; but the one limitation I'm running into is that _all_ problems for a particular matcher are cleared on a run.

For example:
1. I boot up the watch task, and there are problems on `foo.js` and `bar.js`.  The problem matcher picks up on all of these.
2. I make a change to `foo.js`:
   
   a. The watch task re-runs checks for just `foo.js`.
   b. The problem matcher notices that a re-run has occurred, and blows away all problems of that type
   c. Only problems for `foo.js` are listed, even though `bar.js` still has issues.

I'd like to avoid building a language server or plugin for this if I can (the watch task is very useful to non VS code users on the team; and problem matchers are wonderfully simple).

Or maybe we could have an option for only clearing problems for files that have changed (or that match a particular expression?)

data.title: Allow extensions to set configuration options.
data.body:
I've got an extension that I'm currently adding telemetry too so that I can better understand how people are using it, however I want to give users an easy way to opt out of this telemetry collection. My initial thoughts were that I would display a quick pick with two options (agree or disagree) and that I would then store their choice for later executions.

However, it looks like the configuration API for extensions doesn't support the option to set a configuration value. It would be great if I could do something like this:

``` typescript
let configuration = vscode.workspace.getConfiguration('ecdc');
configuration.set('collectTelemetry', false);
```

I'm sure other extensions would find this useful as well to help guide users to setting up sensitive defaults.

data.title: Update extension hangs
data.body:
1. Create a new extension with yo code (just a TypeScript basic extension.
2. Publish to the gallery
3. Install on VS Code
4. Update the extension version and republish to the gallery
5. Extensions: Show Outdated Extensions
6. You see that a new version of the extension is available.  Click Update extension.
   The dropdown stays open with the Update extension button swirling.  It never stops.
   If you change focus, the dropdown goes away but no Restart message comes up.
   If you look under .vscode/extensions, the extension folder is still there containing just the node-modules folder and the .vsixmanifest files.

data.title: Extension API - Modify file name colors / opacity

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is a similar request to #178, but slightly different. 

I want the ability to write an extension to change the opacity / color of file names in the file tree. 

My specific use case is to show what files are being ignored by gitignore.

data.title: Syntax highlighting for batch is broken.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
A common way to strip double-quotes from a variable in Windows Batch Language:
set my_var=%my_var:"=%

But, VS code syntax highlighter thinks that the double-quote in the line above is starting a string, and so, it highlights all code in the file beyond that double-quote until it finds another double-quote in the file, as if it were part of a string, which is isn't.

data.title: Feat.Req.: API: showInputBox() user input validation and feedback
data.body:
It would be nice if we could validate user input before they dismiss with "ok", i.e. show the user they write something we won't accept before they dismiss the inputbox.

This could be a red outline around the inputbox if value doesnt pass validation, ideally would have a message shown underneath telling them what we expect.

A regex and (optional?) default message could work for many cases, ideally a custom validator that allows us to accept/reject (with optional message?) on user input change.

Possible duplicate of this, but this even goes a little further I think:

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/426

data.title: Read first line of file and use as filename when saving

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: If you open a new tab in VS Code and type, say, `test.js`, then you press CTRL + S and dialog pops up: Notice that it's not aware of the `test.js` we just typed. In sublime, if you do this, it will be smart enough to pick up *.js as file type and use `test` as the file name, which is quite handy. I'm not saying you should 100% copycat sublime however in terms of saving a new file, sublime gives a much better developer experience.

data.title: Changing casing of file name shows the file as unsaved even though autoSave: on
data.body:
- auto save: on
- change the casing of file, e.g debugService.ts -> DebugService.ts
- notice that the file appears in working files as unsaved
- I would expect the file is saved as I have auto save on

Even weirder if I do this for one more file now I still have only one unsaved file and that is the newest changed file.

data.title: Add to watch adds an invalid expression

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I have an array of objects, each of which object exposes two fields. I inspect the array in the debugger, expand one of the items in the array, then right click on one of the fields and 'Add to Watch'. E.g., I click on myArray[1].firstField then choose add to watch. I expect to see myArray[1].firstField added as a watch expression but instead I get myArray.[1].firstField  (a dot is added between myArray and the array index.

See below:
![debugger](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1704059/11839123/4fb3e4d6-a3e3-11e5-9964-a176703ebaad.gif)

data.title: Why do we have to specify ES5/ES6 target?
data.body:
This isn't strictly an issue, but a colleague of mine said he didn't understand why it was necessary to specify an ES target.

He said he started using arrow functions and let statements and the editor underlined them in red stating that if he wants to use ES6 then he should set the target in his jsconfig file to ES6. He said if the editor was smart enough to give a descriptive error message, then it should be smart enough to automatically use ES6.

So that brings me to the question. Why do we have to explicitly specify ES5/ES6 target? I am aware that WebStorm also requires you to set ES6 for the project, and I am aware that code completion etc is provided by a modern modular compiler, and being a compiler it needs to know what language version you want to work on. But I still wanted to know if you could comment further on this.
